title: What are the most readable philosophical works by the famous philosophers (basically whoever appears in an outline of philosophy)? - Quora

response.answer_text: There are lots of good anthologies of introductory texts in philosophy, with some Plato, Descartes, Hume, Locke etc. They are all fairly readable.  But I do have a favourite for sheer clarity of style and approachability. I would recommend reading AJ Ayer's Language, Truth, and Logic. Despite its errors and problems (and which philosophical work doesn't have those?), it is a focused work that pulls no punches. I read it when I was 15 or so, and I still recall the pleasure it gave me. There are lots of other choices. Peter Singer is a crystal clear contemporary writer on ethics, Voltaire was a great writer, Hume (though a little archaic to modern eyes) always wrote with purpose and drive.

It depends on your own proclivities I suppose, but I think the following philosophical works are well-written and lucid in argumentation.  Plato - Euthyphro Aristotle - Categories St. Augustine - Confessions Boethius - Consolation of Philosophy Descartes - Meditations on First Philosophy Locke - An Essay Concerning Human Understanding Hobbes - Leviathan Hume - Dialogues Concerning Natural Religion Kant - Prolegomena to Any Future Metaphysics
